Award.AwardTitle: RCN-UBE: Faculty Development Network for Undergraduate Biology (FDN-UB)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This RCN-UBE network project seeks to advance the professional development of undergraduate biology faculty to improve teaching and learning of biology consistent with changes in undergraduate biology education that are called for in the Vision and Change report. Progress in faculty development has been hampered by limited interaction among faculty members, science education researchers, and higher education experts from across different institutional types, geographic locations, and demographic categories. This network will create, build, and support a community of practitioners who will analyze the state of the field of professional development, identify gaps in the practice of professional development, then engage professional societies and other organizations to engage in a series of coordinated and collaborative efforts to improve of faculty development. The goal is that improved opportunities for faculty development should enhance biology teaching and learning in all institutional contexts.

The Faculty Development Network for Undergraduate Biology will foster exchanges and partnerships between the major constituencies essential for effective biology faculty development through use of idea-generating network cluster meetings, all-network synthesis meetings, smaller working group meetings, and online collaboration tools. A Standards of Practice Working Group is synthesizing best practices, and compiling information and resources for professional development in biology education and for broader professional development communities. A Research Working Group is identifying gaps and disconnects in our understanding and/or practice of biology professional development as a starting point for developing future cross-institutional research projects to address questions related to best practices and ways to motivate and sustain change. Through the activities of the Sustaining Change Working Group, the network is partnering with centers, institutes, and national organizations to identify strategies for providing the local, institution-based follow-up needed to sustain changes initiated at national conferences and workshops. The network as a whole is interfacing with biology professional societies to develop society-based teams with common goals and materials for professional development in biology teaching and learning.

This project is funded jointly by the Directorate for Biological Sciences and the Directorate of Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education in support of efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Education: A Call to Action http://visionandchange.org/finalreport/

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main purpose of the Faculty Developer Network for Undergraduate Biology (FDN-UB) project was to create, build, support and sustain a community of practitioners and scholars to advance professional development in (PD) for undergraduate biology educators. The FDN-UB engaged faculty members, science education researchers, and higher education experts from across the country in a network comprised of representatives from different types of institutions, geographic locations, demographic categories and levels of expertise in biology faculty PD. The collaborations needed to achieve the project goals were carried out through use of idea- and product-generating network cluster (working group) meetings, all-network synthesis meetings, and online collaboration tools.

Professional developers work with instructors at colleges and universities across the country who may teach up to thousands of students each year, and each year that number of instructors and students multiplies. Thus, the real and potential impacts of this work on biology education is high. In the past two decades, the science education research community that informs the practices of the professional developers has come to understand more and more about what can work in the classroom to improve understanding of difficult concepts, to increase self-efficacy in students, to promote active learning, and to deal with equity and inclusion issues. However, getting current faculty to be aware of what is happening in their classroom and getting faculty to use active learning and inquiry instruction while addressing the multiple student issues has been lagging. Even if faculty have been introduced to contemporary teaching and learning methods, getting them to use these methods throughout their class is another of the main issues to improved instruction. Additionally, when faculty do attend professional development workshops and seek to change their teaching, the support and incentives necessary to make the changes successful and to sustain them are often lacking.

Activities of two of the working groups in particular can be used as examples of how the network contributed to motivating and sustaining faculty change in teaching. An Introductory Biology Working Group (a Task Force) was specifically designed to address what we do not know about in terms of what works in professional development to improve the awareness and effective use of evidence-based instructional practices. The Task Force members discussed plans for high-impact professional development opportunities across the country for Introductory Biology instructors that were to take place through a series of annual regional workshops that would reach hundreds of instructors and create regional networks of biology instructors. The Task Force designed and offered online PD workshops in the post-Covid era that addressed major challenges of online teaching of introductory biology - these courses are often large enrollment, which makes it even more challenging to maintain the effectiveness of evidence-based teaching strategies such as active learning in an online setting. An Inclusive Teaching Working Group developed a professional development model aimed at addressing a major issue in biology teaching: best teaching practices for fostering equity and inclusiveness with respect to students' academic and professional success. The foundations of their Deep Teaching Residency model include an extended period of self-reflection and discussion, followed by a period for translating this heightened awareness into future teaching practices and other interactions with students. The residency model also promoted leadership in effective dissemination of the experiences, models, and new teaching practices upon return to campus, thus amplifying its considerable impact on classroom and campus culture beyond what it has on individual participants.

There are numerous ways in which important features of both higher education and workforce development are changing. These include rapid changes in biology as a discipline (particularly as it faces evolving challenges such as pandemics and climate change), and in the diversity of the student population. Additionally, employers want educators to foster professional skills (such as higher order thinking) that transcend the content knowledge of individual disciplines such as biology. These changes lend urgency to increasing the use of effective pedagogical approaches that can promote deeper learning for all students and address issues of inclusivity and equity. Professional development is designed to provide faculty with new tools to address this expanding list of expectations ? it aims at translating research into the most effective practices for enhancing student cognitive development and learning. This professional developer's network has been serving as a forum to disseminate effective models for these high impact practices, and generate plans for new, needed research towards the ultimate goal of supporting student success in the evolving academic and science workforce landscape.
